section.title: Prospective and Retrospective Form of Outstanding Balance
section.p: There are two ways to find the outstanding balance at time t, the prospective method and the retrospective method. The prospective method is "forward looking," meaning we use K_{t+1}, K_{t+2}, \ldots, K_n to find OB_t. The retrospective is "backwards looking," meaning we use K_1, K_2, \ldots, K_t to find OB_t.

statement.p: The prospective form of the outstanding balance of a loan is the version that equates the outstanding balance with the present value of the remaining payments. Make a timeline and write a formula to represent the prospective form.

The retrospective form of the outstanding balance uses only the payments already made: K_1, \ldots, K_t (this also requires the loan amount L and the interest rate \iota). By carefully valuing both L and the previous payments at time t, make a timeline and write a formula to represent the prospective form.

introduction.p: A loan of 150,000 is to be repaid with payments of 899.33 at the end of each month for 30 years. The interest rate on the loan is 6% convertible monthly.

task.p: Find the balance OB_{27} using the prospective method.
Find the balance OB_{27} using the retrospective method.

assemblage.title: 🧮 Calculator Tip
assemblage.p: If payments are constant, after you enter in all of the information about a loan (and having the financial calculator find any missing values), you can mimic the retrospective method on the calculator to find OB_t by setting N equal to t and using CPT FV. You can also use the AMORT worksheet.

introduction.p: Solve the following two problems. Think strategically about how you find the outstanding balance in each case.

task.p: A loan of 10,000 is being repaid by installments of 2000 at the end of each year, and a smaller final payment made one year after the last regular payment. Interest is at the effective rate of 12%. Find the amount of the outstanding loan balance remaining when the borrower has made payments equal to the amount of the loan. Answer to the nearest dollar.

A loan is amortized over five years with monthly payments at a nominal interest rate of 9% compounded monthly. The first payment is 1000 and is to be paid one month from the date of the loan. Each succeeding monthly payment will be 2% lower than the prior payment. Calculate the outstanding loan balance immediately after the 40th payment is made.

statement.p: How are you going to decide whether to use the prospective or retrospective method to find the outstanding balance in a problem?
